CertForm.name: Z-Wave Plus v2 Certification
CertForm.formDescription: This is the Z-Wave Plus v2 certification form for General Products, Software and Hardware Devices. This form must be used if the product uses 700 series chips.

formItem.itemTitle: All purchase orders for Z-Wave ASICs/Modules MUST be matched to specific device certifications
formItem.itemDescription:
• Purchase orders that cannot be matched to device certifications will be placed on hold
  • This section provides the details needed by Silicon Labs Sales Department to match the PO to the certification

The company placing the purchase orders for the Z-Wave modules/ASICs MUST include the Z-Wave Certification Number on the PO.
This identifies what company the submitted device is for.

formItem.itemNote: Select this option if the device will be sold/marketed under the submitting company's brand to one or more resellers/customers.
Select this option if the device will be manufactured for a different company using their brand and sold by them to resellers or end users.
This section is to identify any development partners or contractors involved in the project

formItem.itemDescription: Company Owned Facility - No Outside Contractors/Partners

formItem.itemNote: If the contract manufacturer will be placing the purchase orders for the Z-Wave modules/ASICS then they MUST include the certification number for this device on their P.O.

formItem.itemTitle: Type of Z-Wave Plus v2 Certification

formItem.itemNote:
New certifications MUST be based on Active or Maintained SDKs.

This selection is for new devices, not a variation of a previously certified device (unless there are major changes being made). Please refer to the Certification Overview document for details and examples.
Refer to the Certification Overview and/or Fee Schedule to determine whether the changes being made qualify this submission as a Product Modification or a Limited Product Modification.

formItem.itemDescription: Issues in previous Z-Wave Plus v2 certification attempt of same product
Update of a certified Z-Wave device to Z-Wave Plus v2
formItem.itemNote: Due to the number of changes required to convert a classic or Z-Wave Plus device to Z-Wave Plus v2 and the level of testing required to verify compliance to Z-Wave Plus v2 specifications, these updates do not qualify as re-certifications.

The "Clone for Re-Certification" function MUST be used to create Re-Certification cases.
Re-Certifications MUST be based on Active, Maintained or Monitored SDKs.

formItem.itemDescription: Certification or Case Number this submission is based on.

formItem.itemNote: Refer to the Certification Overview and/or Fee Schedule to determine whether the changes being made qualify this submission as a Product Modification or a Limited Product Modification.

formItem.itemDescription: Limited issues in previous Z-Wave Plus v2 certification attempt of same product

formItem.itemNote: Make sure you have selected Silicon Labs as the test partner for this.

formItem.itemDescription: Technical change that does not affect Z-Wave network behavior (review only) - Describe changes below
formItem.itemNote: Make sure you have selected Silicon Labs as the test partner for this.
Hardware and software of product are being certified

formItem.itemDescription: DUT has an integrated Z-Wave ASIC/Module
DUT utilizes an add-on Z-Wave ASIC/Module in a standard hardware interface
formItem.itemNote: Examples: USB stick, Raspberry Pi daughter-card

formItem.itemDescription: Add-On is being certified with this device and will be included with it when shipped
formItem.itemNote: Note: Add-On cannot be sold or shipped separately!

formItem.itemDescription: Z-Wave Plus v2 Software Application Product
formItem.itemNote: Software is certified; requires Certified Z-Wave Platform product to run on

formItem.itemDescription: Z-Wave Plus v2 Hardware Platform Product
formItem.itemNote: Hardware together with sample application software is being certified; must use and expose standard Z-Wave Plus v2 Serial API to host application (not a standalone end user product)

formItem.itemTitle: Z-Wave Plus Developerâs Kit version (API version)
formItem.itemNote: New Z-Wave products can only be certified provided they are based on âActive or âMaintainedâ Z-Wave releases. Recertifications may also be based on or âMonitoredâ Z-Wave releases. (âBetaâ and âObsoleteâ Z-Wave releases cannot be used). Beta releases can be identified by a trailing â0â in the main branch identifier. Examples include 5.00, 4.50 and 6.50 (the trailing zero is underlined). Please do not confuse this with a new active SDK like 4.55.00 or 6.51.00 where the â00â is used to identify it as the initial release.

The library used MUST have been published by Silicon Labs and support all of the functionality required in the Z-Wave Plus Device and Role Type specifications (SDS14224 and SDS11846).

formItem.itemDescription:
The Gateway Device Type is intended for all gateway controllers that provide access in and potentially out of the Z-Wave network as well as extensive controlling capabilities over Z-Wave. This DT MAY provide transparent access for all types of IP Packets between several network technologies.

The Gateway DT MUST be used if the Client/Application UI is running on somewhere else than the same box or LAN network where the controller is running.
formItem.itemNote: Note: The Gateway DT is the correct replacement for all CSC based Controllers from the Z-Wave Plus v1 program.

This can only be used if a Role Type for this Device Type is stated in the Specifications but is not yet listed in the form.

The Role Type name has to be specified in the Role Type form section.

formItem.itemDescription:
The Generic Controller Device Type is intended for all more constrained or simple controllers allowing users to make basic use of the Z-Wave network and controlling a pre-defined set of actuator nodes as well as unknown actuator nodes.

The Generic controller DT MUST NOT be used if the Client/Application UI is running somewhere else then the same box or LAN network where the controller is running.
formItem.itemNote: Note: The Gateway DT is the correct replacement for all CSC based Controllers from the Z-Wave Plus v1 program.

This can only be used if a Role Type for this Device Type is stated in the Specifications but is not yet listed in the form.

The Role Type name has to be specified in the Role Type form section.

The Role Type name has to be specified in the Role Type form section.

formSection.name: Multi Channel End Points
formSection.sectionDescription: In this section the implemented Multi Channel End Points of the DUT are defined. Please proceed to the next page if your device does not support the Multi Channel Command Class.

formItem.itemTitle: The device implements Multi Channel End Points.
formItem.itemNote: A Device Type MUST be assigned to each End Point. End Points may have different Device Types but must share a common Role Type that is approved for use with all of the identified Device Types

formItem.itemDescription: The device supports optional Command Classes on this End Point.

formItem.itemNote: Note: Select all Command Classes from the drop down list that are supported on this End Point but are NOT mandatory for the selected Device Type of this End Point.

formItem.itemDescription: The Lock Device Type is intended for nodes implementing a lock mechanism with optional handles. It can be a door lock, a lockbox as well as a safe.

The Lock Device Type MUST use the following Device Classes:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_ENTRY_CONTROL (0x40)
  • SPECIFIC_TYPE_DOOR_LOCK (0x01)
The Lock requests the following Security Class as the highest Class:
The Lock also requests the S2 Authenticated Security Class
The Lock also requests the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Lock MUST support the following Command Classes:
Recommended optional command classes, if having a keypad:
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Additional supported command classes

formItem.itemDescription: The Basic Command Class MUST be mapped according to Table "Lock Device Type Basic mapping" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Basic Command Class Requirements

formItem.itemDescription: The Motorized barrier Device Type is intended for barriers, gates or garage doors devices.

The Motorized Barrier Device Type MUST use the following Generic Device Class:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_ENTRY_CONTROL (0x40)
The Motorized Barrier Device Type MUST use one of the following Specific Device Classes based on its capabilities within the Barrier Operator Command Class:
• SPECIFIC_TYPE_SECURE_GATE (0x06) if it can both open and close
The Motorized Barrier requests the following Security Class as the highest Class:
The Motorized Barrier also requests the S2 Authenticated Security Class
The Motorized Barrier also requests the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Motorized Barrier MUST support the following Command Classes:
The Basic Command Class MUST be mapped according to Table "Motorized Barrier Device Type Basic mapping" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Basic Command Class Requirements

formItem.itemDescription: The Color Switch Device Type is intended for a lighting product having the ability to change its color.
The Color Switch Device is based on the following Command Class:

The Color Switch Device Type MUST use the following Generic Device Class:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_SWITCH_BINARY (0x10)
  • SPECIFIC_TYPE_COLOR_TUNABLE_BINARY (0x02)
The Color Switch MUST support the Binary Switch Command Class, version 2
The Basic Command Class MUST be mapped according to Table "Color Switch Device Type Basic mapping for Binary Switch" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Basic Command Class Requirements

formItem.itemDescription:
The Color Switch Device Type MUST use the following Generic Device Class:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_SWITCH_MULTILEVEL (0x11)
  • SPECIFIC_TYPE_COLOR_TUNABLE_MULTILEVEL (0x02)
The Color Switch MUST support the Multilevel Switch Command Class, version 4
The Basic Command Class MUST be mapped according to Table "Color Switch Device Type Basic mapping for Multilevel Switch" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Basic Command Class Requirements

formItem.itemDescription: The Color Switch requests the following Security Class as the highest Class:
The Color Switch MUST also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Color Switch MAY also request the S2 Authenticated Security Class
The Color Switch MAY also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Color Switch MUST support the following Command Classes:
The Window Covering Device Type is intended for curtains or blinds allowing the end user to control the amount of light going through windows.

The Window Covering Device Type Type MUST use the following Generic Device Class:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_SWITCH_MULTILEVEL (0x11)
The Window Covering Device Type MUST use one of the following Specific Device Classes based on its capabilities within the Window Covering Command Class:
The Window Covering requests the following Security Class as the highest Class:
The Window Covering MUST also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Window Covering MAY also request the S2 Authenticated Security Class
The Window Covering MAY also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Window Covering MUST support the following Command Classes:
Multilevel Switch, version 4 (MUST be redundant to Window Covering, i.e. actuating the same hardware)
The Basic Command Class MUST be mapped according to Table "Window Covering Device Type Basic mapping" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).
formItem.itemWikiLink: DT All - Basic Command Class Requirements

formItem.itemDescription: The Thermostat Device Type is intended by thermostats that support set points and modes. It is typically used for all mainstream thermostats that can support e.g. Heating, Cooling and Fans.

The Thermostat Device Type MUST use the following Device Classes:
  • GENERIC_TYPE_THERMOSTAT (0x08)
  • SPECIFIC_TYPE_THERMOSTAT_GENERAL_V2 (0x06)
The Thermostat requests the following Security Class as the highest Class:
The Thermostat MUST also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class
The Thermostat MAY also request the S2 Authenticated Security Class
The Thermostat MAY also request the S2 Unauthenticated Security Class

The Central Static Controller Role Type is intended for always powered devices which are capable of operating as a central controller. The CSC will be the central device for most network communications and other devices will rely on it for unsolicited information via the lifeline association to the CSC (which is also the SIS). This will enable the user to receive key information without having to perform major network configuration tasks.
The CSC is typically a router, central gateway or some sort of central communication panel.
The CSC MUST support the Static Update Controller (SUC) and SUC node ID Server (SIS) functions.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Support of SUC and SIS functions (CSC)

formItem.itemDescription: The CSC MUST be mains powered and MAY have a battery back-up.
The CSC MUST set the listening flag to 1 in its NIF.
The CSC MUST support and control the S0 and S2 Command Classes.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Support and control of S0 and S2 CC (CSC)

formItem.itemDescription:
The CSC MUST support the following network roles:
  • SIS
  • Secondary controller
  • Inclusion controller

Primary Controller: It is the controller that is used to set up and maintain a network. It can include/exclude nodes and knows the network topology. When no SUC/SIS is present in the network, other controllers included by the Primary Controller MUST become Secondary Controllers.

Static Update Controller (SUC): When a controller is configured as SUC, the Primary Controller automatically sends network updates to the SUC. The SUC is in charge of keeping the network topology map up to date and deliver it to any controller upon request.

SUC ID Server (SIS): When a SUC is also configured as SIS, it enables other controllers to include/exclude nodes on its behalf, by granting NodeIDs for the nodes to include. The SIS automatically becomes the Primary Controller when enabled.
All static controllers that support SIS functionality MUST accept to become SIS upon request from a Primary Controller.
A static controller operating as Primary Controller that supports SIS functionality MUST assume the SIS role when creating a new network.
Secondary Controller: The Secondary Controller can control nodes but MUST NOT include/exclude nodes. The Secondary Controller MUST NOT provide any other network functionality than Learn Mode.

Inclusion Controller: A controller included in a network with a SIS becomes an Inclusion Controller. It can include/exclude nodes on behalf of the SIS and all network management functionalities supported by the controller MUST be available.

formItem.itemHeader: If first node in the network
formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC is the first node in the network, it MUST set itself the SIS role and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - First node in the network (CSC)

formItem.itemDescription: It MUST NOT be possible to activate Learn Mode if the CSC is the SIS and other nodes are included in the network.

Before removing a non-responsive NodeID from a network, a controller MUST issue NOP commands to the actual NodeID. If the node is not responding, the controller can proceed with removing the NodeID and updating the network.
A responding node MUST NOT be removed from the network.

Additionally, it MAY support the following network function:
  • Replace failing node
The DUT supports the Replace Failed Node function.
Before reusing a non-responsive NodeID to add a new node, a controller MUST issue NOP commands to the actual NodeID.
If the node responds again, the Replace Failed Node MUST be aborted.
The DUT does NOT support the Replace Failed Node function.
If the DUT is the SIS: it MUST set itself as the Association group ID 1 (Lifeline) destination.
If the DUT is not the SIS: it MAY set the SISâ NodeID as the Association group ID 1 (Lifeline) destination.
The DUT MUST assign a return route for the SIS after setting the lifeline of Slave Role Types.
formItem.itemNote:
RT:01.11.0016.1

Details and requirements about establishing the Lifeline are provided in the Command Class Control Specification.

formItem.itemHeader: CSC Setup - CSC including an SSC, PC, RPC or NAS
formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC is the SIS and the included node is of Role Type RPC:
The CSC MUST configure the Wake Up Interval Set Command destination NodeID to its NodeID.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If SIS, set Wake Up destination NodeID to itself

formItem.itemDescription: The CSC MUST send a Wake Up No More Information Command when the CSC has no more command to transmit.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If SIS, set Wake Up destination NodeID to itself

formItem.itemHeader: CSC Setup - CSC including a PS, LSS or RSS
formItem.itemDescription:
If the CSC is the SIS and the included node is of Role Type PS or RSS, the CSC MUST:
  • configure the Wake Up Interval Set Command destination NodeID to its NodeID.
  • send a Wake Up No More Information Command when the CSC has no more command to transmit.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If SIS, set Wake Up destination NodeID to itself

formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC is the SIS and the included node is of Role Type PS:
If the node advertises Wake-Up Capabilities (Wake-Up Command Class, version 2 or newer), the Wake Up Interval Set Command Seconds field MUST be within the allowed range.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Interval Set Command to PS Role Type

formItem.itemDescription: If the node does not advertise Wake-Up Capabilities (Wake-Up Command Class, version 1), the Wake-Up Interval Set Command Seconds field MUST be set to 0.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Interval Set Command to PS Role Type

formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC is not the SIS:
The CSC SHOULD NOT send a Wake Up Interval Set Command to the included node.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If not SIS, CSC does not send Wake Up Interval Set Command (ZWPv2)

formItem.itemDescription: The CSC sends a Wake Up Interval Set Command to the included node.
The destination NodeID MUST be the SIS' NodeID.

formItem.itemHeader: CSC Setup - CSC including another CSC
formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC is included by another CSC, the included CSC MUST take the Inclusion Controller role and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Inclusion of CSC by another CSC

formItem.itemDescription: Before removing a non-responsive NodeID from a network, a controller MUST issue NOP commands to the actual NodeID. If the node is not responding, the controller can proceed with removing the NodeID and updating the network.
A responding node MUST NOT be removed from the network.

Additionally, it MAY support the following network function:
  • Replace failing node
The DUT supports the Replace Failed Node function.
Before reusing a non-responsive NodeID to add a new node, a controller MUST issue NOP commands to the actual NodeID.
If the node responds again, the Replace Failed Node MUST be aborted.
The DUT does NOT support the Replace Failed Node function.

formItem.itemHeader: CSC Setup - CSC included by a PC, RPC, SSC
formItem.itemDescription: The CSC MUST accept to take the SIS role when a PC, RPC or SSC assigns it to the included CSC.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - CSC accepts SIS role when included by PC, RPC or SSC

formItem.itemDescription: If the CSC was assigned the SIS role, previously added nodes may have no lifeline associations. The CSC SHOULD create lifeline associations in all existing nodes that are directly reachable.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - SIS creates Lifeline associations in existing, directly reachable nodes

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
The CSC MUST instruct a reporting node (RPC, RSS, PS) to return to sleep after application data has been delivered to the node. This is done by sending a Wake Up No More Information Command.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up No More Information Command to reporting nodes

formItem.itemDescription: A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes. A controller providing SmartStart inclusion of other nodes MAY also support being included in a network using SmartStart inclusion.
DUT can perform SmartStart inclusion of other nodes

The Sub Static Controller Role Type is intended for static controllers which are not suitable as central controllers. It is aimed at applications that require a static controller to manage a subset of nodes. It is typically offered as a bundled package with e.g. sensors.
The SSC MUST be mains powered and MAY have a battery back-up.
The SSC MUST set the listening flag to 1 in its NIF.
The SSC MUST NOT support the SIS functionality.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - SSC MUST NOT support SIS functionality

formItem.itemDescription: The SSC SHOULD NOT configure lifeline associations.

The SSC MUST support the following network roles:
  • Primary Controller
  • Secondary controller
  • Inclusion controller
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Mandatory network roles (SSC, PC, RPC)

formItem.itemDescription: Primary Controller: It is the controller that is used to set up and maintain a network. It can include/exclude nodes and knows the network topology. When no SUC/SIS is present in the network, other controllers included by the Primary Controller MUST become Secondary Controllers.
If no SIS is present in the network, when including a static controller supporting SIS functionality, the Primary Controller MUST assign the SIS role to the new static controller.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Including a SIS role supporting controller

formItem.itemDescription: Secondary Controller: The Secondary Controller can control nodes but MUST NOT include/exclude nodes. The Secondary Controller MUST NOT provide any other network functionality than Learn Mode.

Inclusion Controller: A controller included in a network with a SIS becomes an Inclusion Controller. It can include/exclude nodes on behalf of the SIS and all network management functionalities supported by the controller MUST be available.

formItem.itemHeader: If first node in the network
formItem.itemDescription: If the SSC is the first node in the network, it MUST take the Primary Controller role and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - First node in the network (Primary Controller)

formItem.itemDescription: It MUST NOT be possible to activate Learn Mode if the SSC is the Primary Controller and other nodes are included in the network.

formItem.itemHeader: SSC Setup - SSC including a CSC
formItem.itemDescription: If the SSC is the Primary Controller and a CSC is added to the network, the SSC MUST assign the SIS role to the CSC.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Primary Controller assigning SIS role to included CSC

formItem.itemDescription: If the SSC is the Primary Controller and has previously included some Wake Up nodes, it MAY re-assign the Wake Up destination NodeID to the CSC/SIS for the previously included Wake Up nodes at the next Wake Up Notification.
The DUT re-assigns the Wake Up destination.
The DUT does NOT re-assign the Wake Up destination.
The SSC becomes an inclusion controller and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Inclusion Controller functionality (SSC, PC, RPC)

formItem.itemHeader: SSC Setup - SSC including an RPC, PS or RSS
formItem.itemDescription: If there is a SIS in the network:
The SSC SHOULD NOT send a Wake Up Interval Set Command to the included node.
formItem.itemNote:
RT:02.12.0003.1

This RECOMMENDED requirement is MANDATORY for Z-Wave Plus v2 because of CL:0084.01.21.01.2.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If SIS present, SSC does not send Wake Up Interval Set Command (ZWPv2)

formItem.itemDescription: If there is no SIS present in the network, the SSC SHOULD send a Wake Up Interval Set Command with its own NodeID as destination.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If no SIS present, Wake Up Interval Set destination NodeID (SSC)

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the above recommendation.
If issuing a Wake Up interval Set Command, the SSC MUST respect the following rules:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Interval Set Command Seconds field (SSC)

formItem.itemDescription: If the included node is of Role Type RPC, PS or RSS the SSC SHOULD set the Wake Up Interval Set Command Seconds field to the default Wake Up time advertised by the included node.
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
If the included node is of Role Type PS:
If the node advertises Wake-Up Capabilities (Wake-Up Command Class, version 2 or newer), the Wake Up Interval Set Command Seconds field MUST be within the allowed range.
If the node does not advertise Wake-Up Capabilities (Wake-Up Command Class, version 1), the Wake-Up Interval Set Command Seconds field MUST be set to 0.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.

A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes. A controller providing SmartStart inclusion of other nodes MAY also support being included in a network using SmartStart inclusion.
DUT can perform SmartStart inclusion of other nodes

The Portable Controller Role Type is intended for portable controllers that can setup and maintain a Z-Wave network but do not require unsolicited reporting. It is typically used by home control remotes that control a few lights.
The PC MUST be battery powered and support the Battery Command Class.
The PC MUST set the listening flag to 0 in its NIF.
The PC SHOULD NOT configure lifeline associations when adding nodes to the network.

The PC MUST support the following network roles:

  • Secondary controller

The Reporting Portable Controller Role Type is intended for portable reporting controllers, which need to setup a Z-Wave network and also send unsolicited messages.
The RPC Role Type may for instance be used for a battery powered thermostat which can include and exclude nodes in a small network. In addition, the thermostat may be configured remotely.

The RPC MUST be battery powered and support the following Command Classes:
  • Battery Command Class
  • Wake Up Command Class, version 2 or newer
The RPC MUST set the listening flag to 0 in its NIF.
The RPC SHOULD NOT configure lifeline associations when adding nodes to the network.

The RPC MUST support the following network roles:
  • Primary Controller
  • Secondary controller
  • Inclusion controller
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Mandatory network roles (SSC, PC, RPC)

formItem.itemDescription: Primary Controller: It is the controller that is used to set up and maintain a network. It can include/exclude nodes and knows the network topology. When no SUC/SIS is present in the network, other controllers included by the Primary Controller MUST become Secondary Controllers.
If no SIS is present in the network, when including a static controller supporting SIS functionality, the Primary Controller MUST assign the SIS role to the new static controller.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Including a SIS role supporting controller

formItem.itemDescription: Secondary Controller: The Secondary Controller can control nodes but MUST NOT include/exclude nodes. The Secondary Controller MUST NOT provide any other network functionality than Learn Mode.

Inclusion Controller: A controller included in a network with a SIS becomes an Inclusion Controller. It can include/exclude nodes on behalf of the SIS and all network management functionalities supported by the controller MUST be available.

formItem.itemHeader: If first node in the network
formItem.itemDescription: If the RPC is the first node in the network, it MUST take the Primary Controller role and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - First node in the network (Primary Controller)

formItem.itemDescription: It MUST NOT be possible to activate Learn Mode if the DUT is the Primary Controller and other nodes are included in the network.
When including a node, if a SIS is present in the network, the RPC MAY set the SISâ NodeID as the Association group ID 1 (Lifeline) destination.
formItem.itemNote:
RT:04.13.0001.1

Details and requirements about establishing the Lifeline are provided in the Command Class Control Specification.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - If SIS present, RPC sets Lifeline destination to SIS

formItem.itemHeader: RPC Setup - RPC including a CSC
formItem.itemDescription: If the RPC is the Primary Controller and a CSC is added to the network, the RPC MUST assign the SIS role to the CSC.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Primary Controller assigning SIS role to included CSC

formItem.itemDescription: The RPC becomes an inclusion controller and MUST support the following network functions:
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Inclusion Controller functionality (SSC, PC, RPC)

formItem.itemDescription: The RPC MUST support the Wake Up Command Class as described in section "Wake-Up communication timeout protection" of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Command Class support

formItem.itemDescription: A battery powered node supporting Wake-Up communication sends a Wake Up Notification Command to get attention when it is awake and receives a Wake Up No More Information Command when it can safely return to sleep.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up and Sleep Commands

formItem.itemDescription: A battery powered Z-Wave Plus node supporting Wake-Up communication SHOULD implement a time-out mechanism which makes the node return to sleep if the node does not receive a Wake Up No More Information Command.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Time-out mechanism for Wake Up Time

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.

If no Wake Up No More Information Command is received from the Wake Up destination, the node MUST respond to the Wake Up destination until 10 seconds have elapsed since the last transmission or reception with the Wake Up destination.
The RPC SHOULD have a physical push button for waking up the device for expedited communication. This enables interactive delivery of new configuration parameters or firmware updates.
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
The RPC MUST implement a Minimum Wake Up Interval in the range 0 ..4200 (i.e. between 0 second and 70 minutes).
If the RPCâs Minimum Wake Up Interval is 0, the RPC MUST implement a Maximum Wake Up Interval greater than 0.
The RPC MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.

The Portable Slave Role Type is intended for battery powered devices that aim for the lowest possible power consumption. The PS only wakes up in response to a physical event such as a button press. The PS allows for optimal cost, as no EEPROM is required.

The PS MUST be battery powered and support the following Command Classes:
  • Battery Command Class
  • Wake Up Command Class, version 2 or newer
The PS MUST set the listening flag to 0 in its NIF.
The PS MUST support the Wake Up Command Class as described in section "Wake-Up communication timeout protection" of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Command Class support

formItem.itemDescription: The PS SHOULD use a default Wake-Up interval of 0.
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
The PS SHOULD have a physical push button for waking up the device for expedited communication. This enables interactive delivery of new configuration parameters or firmware updates.
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
The PS MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.
The Always On Slave Role Type is intended for mains powered devices that are always reachable. One example of such a device is a light switch.
The AOS MUST be mains powered and MAY have a battery back-up.
The AOS MUST set the listening flag to 1 in its NIF. The AOS can only be added to a network and has no network role requirement.
The AOS MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.

The Reporting Sleeping Slave Role Type is intended for battery-powered devices that only wake up and communicates when an event has occurred. This allows to reconfigure the device remotely. Examples include sensors, wall controllers etc.

The RSS MUST be battery powered and support the following Command Classes:
  • Battery Command Class
  • Wake Up Command Class, version 2 or newer
The RSS MUST set the listening flag to 0 in its NIF.

The RSS MUST support the Wake Up Command Class as described in section "Wake-Up communication timeout protection" and figure "Wake Up Command Class" of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up Command Class support

formItem.itemDescription: A battery powered node supporting Wake-Up communication sends a Wake Up Notification Command to get attention when it is awake and receives a Wake Up No More Information Command when it can safely return to sleep.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Wake Up and Sleep Commands

formItem.itemDescription: A battery powered Z-Wave Plus node supporting Wake-Up communication SHOULD implement a time-out mechanism which makes the node return to sleep if the node does not receive a Wake Up No More Information Command.
formItem.itemWikiLink: RT - Time-out mechanism for Wake Up Time

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.

If no Wake Up No More Information Command is received from the Wake Up destination, the node MUST respond to the Wake Up destination until 10 seconds have elapsed since the last transmission or reception with the Wake Up destination.
The device SHOULD have a physical push button for waking up the device for expedited communication. This enables interactive delivery of new configuration parameters or firmware updates.
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
The RSS MUST implement a Minimum Wake Up Interval in the range 0 ..4200 (i.e. between 0 second and 70 minutes).
If the RSSâs Minimum Wake Up Interval is 0, the RSS MUST implement a Maximum Wake Up Interval greater than 0.
The RSS MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.

The Listening Sleeping Slave Role Type is intended for battery-operated devices that can be reached even though they are sleeping thanks to Beaming (FLiRS devices). Examples include Door Locks and Battery operated Thermostats.
The LSS MUST be battery powered and support the Battery Command Class.
The LSS MUST set the listening flag to 0 in its NIF.
The LSS MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
The LSS MUST stay awake for at least 2 seconds after communicating.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.

The Network Aware Slave Role Type is intended for slaves with application controlling capabilities, which are leveraging controller functionalities to be aware of the network topology and nodes capabilities. The SIS (or primary controller) will consider a NAS as a controller, but the NAS will not be able to include new nodes in the network.
The NAS MUST be mains powered and MAY have a battery back-up.
The NAS MUST set the listening flag to 1 in its NIF.
The NAS can only be added to a network and MUST take the inclusion controller or the secondary controller role when added to a network.

The NAS MUST NOT provide the following network functions:
  • Include new nodes
  • Exclude nodes
  • Remove failing node
  • Replace failing node
The NAS MUST communicate via the lifeline association if any lifeline association exists.
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes.
Meets all requirements as specified for this Role Type

A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST either support to be included in a network using SmartStart inclusion or provide SmartStart inclusion of other nodes. A controller providing SmartStart inclusion of other nodes MAY also support being included in a network using SmartStart inclusion.
DUT can perform SmartStart inclusion of other nodes

formItem.itemHeader: How to detect Z-Wave Plus v2 compliant nodes
formItem.itemDescription: A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST advertise version 0x02 in the Z-Wave Plus Version field of the Z-Wave Plus Info Report. Multi Channel End Points MUST advertise the same version number in their Z-Wave Plus Info Report.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Z-Wave Plus Info Report for Z-Wave Plus v2

formItem.itemDescription: A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST set the Optional Functionality bit to 1 in its NIF.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Optional Functionality bit for Z-Wave Plus v2

formItem.itemDescription: The Role Type of a node can be requested via the Z-Wave Plus Info Command Class, which MUST be listed as the first supported Command Class in the Node Information Frame (NIF) by all Z-Wave Plus nodes.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Z-Wave Plus Info Command Class in NIF

formItem.itemDescription:
All Root Devices or nodes MUST support:
  • Association, version 2
  • Association Group Information
  • Device Reset Locally
  • Firmware Update Meta Data, version 5
  • Indicator, version 3
  • Manufacturer Specific
  • Multi Channel Association, version 3
  • Powerlevel
  • Security 2
  • Supervision
  • Transport Service, version 2
  • Version, version 2
  • Z-Wave Plus Info, version 2
formItem.itemWikiLink: Mandatory supported Command Classes for Root Devices or nodes

formItem.itemDescription:
Device Types MAY support optional Command Classes on top of the minimum mandatory set of supported Command Classes. However, the following Command Classes MUST NOT be supported optionally in a Device Type:
  • Motorized barrier
  • Color Switch
  • Window Covering
  • Multilevel Switch
  • Thermostat Mode
  • Thermostat Setpoint
  • Thermostat Setback
  • Sound Switch
  • Simple AV Control
  • Binary Switch
formItem.itemWikiLink: Command Classes MUST NOT be supported optionally

formItem.itemDescription:
It means that if supported, these command classes MUST fit the exact actuator Command Class list of a Device Type. If several actuator Command Classes not belonging to the Device Type need to be supported, they MUST be partitioned in End Points which match the actuator Command Class list of a Device Type.

Multi Channel Root Devices MAY still aggregate some of the above mentioned Command Classes from their end points for backwards compatibility. The optional Command Class rule applies:
  • For the node (Root Device) if the node does not support Multi Channel Command Class
  • For each and every end point if the node supports the Multi Channel Command Class
A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST have a visible LED to be used for an Identify function. If the node is itself a light source, e.g. a light bulb, this MAY be used in place of a dedicated LED.
The Root Device of a node MUST support the Indicator Command Class, version 3 and support the Indicator ID 0x50 (Identify) and Properties ID 0x03, 0x04 and 0x05.
Nodes (and their End Points) MAY change capabilities based on a user action, such as changing configuration parameters or the physical addition/removal of a module.
The DUT can change capabilities based on user interaction.
End Point changing capabilities based on a user action MUST NOT be advertised as Dynamic End Points.

If supporting Configuration Command Class, nodes MAY issue a Configuration Report advertising a dynamic capabilities parameter value change in order to let the lifeline destination(s) know that some capabilities have changed.
The DUT issues a Configuration Report advertising a dynamic capabilities parameter value change.
The DUT does NOT issues a Configuration Report advertising a dynamic capabilities parameter value change.

The configuration of Command Classes that are available before and after a capability change MUST remain unchanged. For instance, the Lifeline Association Group destination and Wake Up destination MUST stay identical when a node changes capabilities.
A node MUST stay compliant and observe Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type requirements when and after changing capabilities. A node MAY change its Device Type when altering its capabilities.

A node being able to change between a secure only Device Type (S2 Access Control) and a regular S2 Device Type MUST observe the S2 Access Control Device Type requirements even if configured to be a regular Device Type.
The DUT can NOT change capabilities.
A Z-Wave Plus compliant node MUST support both Classic and Network Wide Inclusion (NWI)
formItem.itemWikiLink: Network Wide And Classic Inclusion Slave And Controller

formItem.itemDescription: The device MUST be able to issue a Device Reset Locally Command via its Lifeline to notify the Lifeline destination that the device has been reset to its factory default state.
If a device is reset, it MUST perform the reset operation regardless of whether or not the delivery of the Device Reset Locally Notification is successful.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Reset operation without delivery of Device Reset Locally Notification

formItem.itemDescription: It is RECOMMENDED that devices implement a mechanism that allows the user to determine when the reset operation is completed.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Mechanism to determine when reset operation is completed

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.
It MUST forget its current HomeID and consider itself excluded from the network.
The configuration of other Command Classes (Management, Transport or Network) MUST be reset to default (i.e. S2 keys are forgotten, Associations and Wake-Up configurations are cleared, etcâ¦)

During a node capability discovery or interview, as well as traffic generated due to user activation, a controlling nodes MUST timeout waiting for responses (reports) as part of the capability discovery or controlling scenarios.

Two timers named CommandTime and ReportTime are used for timing out during a node discovery interview. Illustrations are given for secure and non-secure cases in Figure "Node interview ReportTime timeout without security" and Figure "Node interview ReportTime timeout with security" of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
  • CommandTime is measured by the application
  • ReportTime timeout SHOULD be set to CommandTime + 1 second

Z-Wave is a radio technology with limited bandwidth. Therefore, it is NOT RECOMMENDED to use polling. If used, polling communication MUST comply with the requirements stated in section "Polling Devices" of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
If the DUT sends Unsolicited Frames it MUST meet the requirements in section âUnsolicited communicationâ of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846)
The DUT MUST meet the requirements in section âRuntime communicationâ of the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846)
The network rediscovery (Request neighbor update) feature SHOULD only be used as last resort in case the runtime communication fails.
The DUT implements a network rediscovery (Request neighbor update) feature.
The DUT does NOT implement a network rediscovery (Request neighbor update) feature.

A number of Z-Wave encapsulation Command Classes exist, they MUST be applied in the following order:
  1. Any one of the following combinations:
    1. Transport Service followed by Security
    2. Transport Service
    3. Security
    4. CRC16
  2. Multi Channel
  3. Supervision
  4. Multi Command
  5. Schedule
  6. Encapsulated Command Class (payload), e.g. Basic Get
formItem.itemNote:
Note: The Transport Service and CRC16 Command Classes are mutually exclusive as well as Security and CRC16.
RT:00.11.0022.1

formItem.itemDescription: Normally, responses to a given command must be carried out using the same encapsulation or lack of encapsulation as it was received, unless specified otherwise in the Command Class specifications.
The transport service MUST be used only if the payload does not fit in the Z-Wave MAC frame size.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Transport Service only used if payload too large for frame size

formItem.itemDescription: The Multi Command Command Class is optional to use and SHOULD be used only if several commands are queued for transmission.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Command CC only used if several commands queued

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT follows the requirements in the "Node Information Frame" section of the Application Command Class Specification (SDS13781).

The following Command Classes MUST always be in the NIF if supported:
  • Application Status Command Class
  • CRC-16 Encapsulation Command Class
  • Inclusion Controller Command Class
  • Multi Command Command Class
  • Security 2 Command Class
  • Supervision Command Class
  • Time Command Class
  • Transport Service Command Class
  • Z-Wave Plus Info Command Class
If present, the list of controlling Command Classes MUST be prepended by the COMMAND_CLASS_MARK Command Class identifier.

A node supporting security (S0 and/or S2) MUST advertise command classes in the NIF according to Table "NIF content depending on inclusion and security bootstrapping" in the Application Command Class Specification (SDS13781).
Command Classes advertised as supported in the NIF after S0/S2 bootstrapping MUST also be supported at higher security levels unless encapsulated outside security.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Non-securely supported CCs are also supported at higher security levels

formItem.itemDescription: A node MUST advertise support for Multi Channel Command Class only if it implements End Points. A node able to communicate using the Multi Channel encapsulation but implementing no End Point MUST NOT advertise support for the Multi Channel Command Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Advertise support for Multi Channel CC only if End Points are implemented

formItem.itemDescription: A node able to receive commands encapsulated with the Transport Service, Security. CRC-16 or Multi Command Command Class MUST advertise the respective Command Class as supported and MUST also be able to send commands encapsulated with the respective Command Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Encapsulation support for Transport Service, Security, CRC-16 and Multi Command

formItem.itemDescription: If a node is temporarily not capable to service a Get or Set Command request, it MUST support the Application Status Command Class and send an Application Busy Report Command to the initiator of the Get or Set.
The DUT is ALWAYS capable of servicing the GET and SET request.
formItem.itemNote: In this case it is OPTIONAL to support the Application Status Command Class.

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT could temporarily not be capable to service a GET or SET command request. It MUST support the Application Status Command Class and send an Application Busy Report Command to the initiator of the Get or Set.
formItem.itemNote: Note: Use the below text field to describe when this happens and how the test house can trigger an Application Busy report during their tests.

formItem.itemDescription: A node MAY send a command to several destinations using a Multicast or Broadcast frame. This is allowed only if the actual command does not require the responding node to return a response.
formItem.itemNote: The Z-Wave Multicast frame, the broadcast NodeID and the Multi Channel multi-End Point destination are all considered multicast addressing methods.

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT sends commands to several destinations using a Multicast or Broadcast frames.
formItem.itemNote: Note: Use the text field to list the commands that are sent to several destinations and explain how they can be sent.

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT does NOT send commands to several destinations.
Unless specified otherwise for a particular command:
Commands requiring another command to be returned in response by a receiving node MUST NOT be issued via multicast addressing in a Z-Wave network.
A receiving node MUST NOT return a response if a command is received via multicast addressing.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Must not return a response to a multicast GET command

formItem.itemDescription:
Regardless of whether a node is a slave or a controller, a node providing Z-Wave functionalities over another technology MUST control the following Command Classes:
  • Door Lock Command Class
  • Binary Switch Command Class
  • Multilevel Switch Command Class
  • Thermostat Mode Command Class
  • Thermostat Setpoint Command Class
The DUT provides Z-Wave functionalities over another technology.
The DUT does NOT provide Z-Wave functionalities over another technology.

formSection.name: Application Command Classes
formSection.sectionDescription:
In this and the following three sections you identify which version of a Command Class is being implemented and its role (âSupportâ and/or âControlâ).
  • If a Command Classes is only controlled via Association Groups, the "Control" role for this Command Class MUST NOT be selected.
  • All Command Classes supported and/or fully controlled by this device MUST be listed in this and the following three sections. This includes the already preselected mandatory CCs according the Device and Role Type of this product as well as any recommended or optional Command Classes that have been implemented. "Full" control means the device implements the ability to interview, read and/or set other nodes supporting the Command Class.
  • When a Command Class is marked as controlled in the form, the controlling node MUST observe the requirements for the Command Class defined in the Command Class Control specification (SDS14223).
  • Select only the highest version of the Command Class supported and/or fully controlled. If the device supports and controls different versions of the same Command Class please select the highest of both versions and use the comment function on this Command Class form item to leave a note for the test house.
  • The Device Type Specification may list a minimum CC version requirement as mandatory. The developer does have the option of changing the preselected item to a higher version if one is available.
  • For instructions on how to test supported and controlled Command Classes please visit the Application Support wiki page.

formItem.itemDescription: If a Command Class is supported: The node implements all the Command Class functionalities and can be set and read back by other nodes. When a Command Class is supported, the node is REQUIRED to implement the whole Command Class and observe the requirements specified in the Command Class Specifications (SDS13781, SDS13782, SDS13783, SDS13784).
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support Requirements for all command classes

formItem.itemDescription:
Except for the following explicitly listed Device Types, Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Types MUST NOT support Anti Theft Command Class:
  • Lock
  • Thermostat

The Root Device and End Points of a Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST advertise the Association Groups indicated in table "Z-Wave Plus v2 minimum required AGI table" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224) as a minimum.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Advertising Lifeline association group in AGI

formItem.itemDescription: A Node or Root Device MUST advertise a âMax Nodes Supportedâ value of 1 or more for the Lifeline Association group in the Association Report and Multi Channel Association Report Commands.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Advertising Lifeline association group size

formItem.itemDescription: A Z-Wave Plus v2 node MUST issue all the commands defined in document Association Command Class, list of mandatory commands for the Lifeline Association Group (SDS14222) via the Lifeline Association Group to reflect its state changes if the corresponding command is supported by the node.
If the state change was triggered by other means than a Z-Wave Command, a node MUST issue the corresponding Report/Notification Command immediately to the lifeline destination(s).
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Reports for non-command state changes

formItem.itemDescription: If the state change was triggered by a Z-Wave Command:
A node MUST NOT issue any Report/Notification Command after a Command received via Multicast/broadcast addressing.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Reporting after multicast or broadcast addressing

formItem.itemDescription: Unless the lifeline destination issued the command, a node MUST issue a Report/Notification Command after a command was received using singlecast addressing (including Multi Channel multi-End Point destination) via the Lifeline.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Reporting after singlecast addressing

formItem.itemDescription: If a node has more than one lifeline destination, it MUST issue a Report/Notification Command after a command was received using singlecast addressing (including Multi Channel multi-End Point destination) via the Lifeline.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Lifeline support - Reporting to multiple destinations

formItem.itemDescription: The Z-Wave Plus certification program mandates that association group 1 is reserved for the Lifeline association group. Association group 1 MUST NOT be assigned to any other use than the Lifeline group.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Association Group 1 MUST be used for Lifeline association

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT supports the Association Version 3 or the Multichannel Association Version 4 Command Class.
If a node supports the version 3 of the Association Command Class and the Multi Channel Association Command Class, it MUST support the Multi Channel Association Command, version 4 or newer.
If a node supports the version 4 of the Multichannel Association Command Class and the Association Command Class, it MUST support the Association Command, version 3 or newer.
Any supporting node MUST learn the granted security classes of a destination before sending controlling commands to a destination via association groups.
formItem.itemNote:
Note: It is recommended to follow the discovery sequence listed in section "Association Command Class, version 3 - Interoperability considerations" of the Z-Wave Management Command Class Specification (SDS13782).
CC:0085.03.00.31.001, CC:0085.03.00.32.001
formItem.itemWikiLink: Controlling via association - Security Class learning

formItem.itemDescription:
When issuing (supporting or controlling) commands via an association group:
  • A supporting node MUST NOT use Supervision encapsulation if the destination does not supports the Supervision Command Class.
  • A supporting node MUST use Supervision encapsulation if the destination supports the Supervision Command Class.

When issuing (supporting or controlling) commands via an association group:
  • A supporting node MUST NOT use Multi Command encapsulation if the destination does not supports the Multi Command Command Class.
If the Configuration Command Class is implemented, it MUST NOT replace any existing Command Class functionality.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support of Configuration CC - MUST not replace Command Class functionality

formItem.itemDescription: If the Configuration Command Class is supported, it MUST be version 4 as a minimum.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support of Configuration CC - Minimum version is 4

formItem.itemTitle: Firmware Update Meta Data Command Class

formItem.itemDescription: The configuration of Command Classes that are available before and after a firmware update MUST remain unchanged. For instance, the Lifeline Association Group destination, Wake Up destination and any command class setting MUST stay identical before and after performing a firmware update.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support of Firmware Update Md CC - Configuration of Command Classes

formItem.itemDescription: In order to increase interoperability with legacy controlling nodes, a node supporting the Security 0 Command Class MUST reply to Manufacturer Specific Get Commands received non-securely if it was granted the S0 network key as its highest Security Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support of Manufacturer Specific CC - Security S0

formItem.itemDescription: If the node supports the Wake Up Command Class, the node MUST support manual Wake Up triggered by a user activation.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Support of Wake Up CC - Wake Up triggered by user activation

formItem.itemDescription:
All Multi Channel End Points MUST support:
  • Association, version 2
  • Association Group Information
  • Multi Channel Association, version 3
  • Supervision
  • Z-Wave Plus Info, version 2
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Mandatory Command Classes for End Points

formItem.itemDescription: Multi Channel devices MAY support an Identify indicator on End Points, if the corresponding End Point has its own LED or light source.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Own Identify indicator on End Point

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT supports Identify indicators on End Points.
The DUT does NOT support Identify indicators on End Points.
If a Multi Channel device only implements a single indicator for the entire device, the End Points MUST NOT support the Identify Indicator, while the Root Device MUST support the Identify Indicator.

End Points MUST advertise a âMax Nodes Supportedâ of 0 for the Lifeline Group and MUST report their Lifeline Commands via the Root Deviceâs Lifeline Group when an End Point Association is established for the Lifeline Group. (Refer to Multi Channel Association Command Class)
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Advertising Lifeline association group size of End Points

formItem.itemDescription: Actuator functionalities MUST reside in individual Multi Channel End Points according to the list of actuator Device Types.
Multi Channel devices MUST support the Multi Channel Command Class, version 4 or newer
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Minimum version of Multi Channel CC is 4

formItem.itemDescription: A node supporting the Multi Channel Command Class MUST issue commands to the Lifeline destination from all of its End Points if an End Point Association has been established on the Root Device Lifeline association group.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Lifeline reporting for End Points

formItem.itemDescription: A command issued to the Lifeline destination from a Multi Channel End Point MUST be Multi Channel encapsulated if an End Point Association has been established.
A Multi Channel device MUST implement all application functionality in End Points.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - All application functionality must reside in End Points

formItem.itemDescription: End Point 1 MUST implement the primary application functionality of the actual Multi Channel device.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Primary application functionality must reside in End Point 1

formItem.itemDescription: For backwards compatibility, the Root Device MUST mirror the application functionality of End Point 1.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - End Point 1 capabilities

formItem.itemDescription: Further, the Root Device MAY mirror the application functionalities of additional End Points. As an example, Basic Off and On commands for the Root Device may control all outlets of a power strip with five outlets.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Application functionality of additional End Points

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT mirrors application functionalities of additional End Points to the Root Device.
formItem.itemNote: Note: Use the text field to list which functionalities are mirrored.

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT does NOT mirror application functionalities of additional End Points.
With the exception of dynamic End Points, the Root Device MUST advertise all End Point functionality which is mirrored by the Root Device.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Mirroring of fixed End Point functionality

formItem.itemDescription: The Root Device of a Multi Channel device MUST NOT advertise any application functionality that cannot be reached via one or more End Points.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Root Device does not advertise any application functionality not reachable via End Points

formItem.itemDescription: It MUST NOT be possible to limit the functionality, or enable non-compliant behavior of any End Point in the device by sending a command to the Root Device.
Multi Channel Root Devices MUST advertise their non-secure capabilities via the NIF.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Advertising the non-secure capabilities

formItem.itemDescription: Multi Channel End Points MUST advertise their non-secure capabilities via the Multi Channel Capability Report Command.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Advertising the non-secure capabilities

formItem.itemDescription: Security bootstrapped nodes MUST advertise their capabilities using security encapsulation (for both Root Devices and End Points) via the S0 Security Commands Supported Report Command or the S2 Security 2 Commands Supported Report Command.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Advertising the secure capabilities

formItem.itemDescription: An End Point MAY be dynamic. Dynamic End points are intended End Points able to change their capabilities or that can be added and removed from a Multi Channel device.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Implementation of dynamic End Points

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT implements dynamic End Points.
When a dynamic End Point is removed, all other End Points MUST maintain their current End Point identifiers.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Maintenance of identifiers for dynamic End Points

formItem.itemDescription: After advertising the removal, a removed dynamic End Point MUST ignore all commands.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Removed dynamic End Points must ignore commands

formItem.itemDescription: A node MUST NOT advertise changes to dynamic End Points via broadcast transmission.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Multi Channel support - Advertising changes of dynamic End Points via broadcast

formItem.itemDescription: The DUT does NOT implement dynamic End Points.

formItem.itemTitle: The DUT implements the following type of Command Class Control
The DUT has one or more Full Controlled Command Classes
formItem.itemNote:
Note: This field is automatically pre-selected if at least one Command Class has its role set to "Control" in the Command Class for sections above.
If this device controls Command Classes ONLY via Association Groups please do NOT select the "Control" role for any Command Classes.

formItem.itemDescription: If a Command Class is controlled: The node implements the ability to interview, read and/or set other nodes supporting the Command Class. Nodes controlling Command Classes MAY use a subset of the Commands within a Command Class (for example only Set commands).

When a Command Class is marked as controlled during certification, the controlling node is said to implement "full" control of the actual Command Class and it MUST observe the requirements for the Command Class defined in the Command Class Control specification (SDS14223) .
formItem.itemWikiLink: Controlling - Full control of a Command Class

formItem.itemDescription: The Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224) mandates some nodes to control a given set of Command Classes. It means that the controlling node MUST respect the requirements described in this document for the actual Command Classes.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Controlling - Full control of a Command Class Set

formItem.itemDescription: A controlling node MUST read the capabilities and secure capabilities of a node/End Point once before trying to control a given Command Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Command Classes support discovery requirements - read capabilities

formItem.itemDescription: A controlling node MUST read the Command Class version number of a supporting node using the Version Command Class prior to controlling the Command Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Command Classes support discovery requirements - read version number

formItem.itemDescription: A node controlling a given command class MUST allow an end user to control the command class in all listening supporting nodes present in the network operating with a security class that is granted to the controlling node.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Command Classes support discovery requirements - user interaction (listening nodes)

formItem.itemDescription: A node controlling a Command Class MUST allow an end user to control a sleeping supporting node if it is the Wake Up destination.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Command Classes support discovery requirements - user interaction (sleeping nodes)

formItem.itemDescription: This interview MUST be performed prior to issuing any control command to the supporting node.
formItem.itemNote:
Preferably, it should be done during the commissioning phase of the supporting node or shortly after the inclusion of the controlling node.

CL:0000.00.21.02.1

formItem.itemDescription: A controlling node MUST NOT skip or abort the interview of a Command Class if another independent Command Class could not be correctly interviewed.

The following order for reading Command Class capabilities is RECOMMENDED after discovering the Security Class and encapsulation capabilities of a node:
  • Version Command Class
  • Z-Wave Plus Info Command Class
  • Wake Up Command Class
  • Association OR Multi Channel Association Command Class
  • Association Group Information (AGI) Command Class
  • Actuator Command Classes
  • Data reporting Command Classes
  • Multi Channel Command Class (and repeat the above order for each End Point, if any)
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.

Some interviews or controlling scenarios may trigger no response in return to get type commands. In this case, it is RECOMMENDED to use timeouts according to the Z-Wave Plus Role Type Specification (SDS11846).
The DUT follows the above recommendation.
The DUT does NOT follow the above recommendation.

The minimum end user functionalities section in the Command Class Control Specification (SDS14223) specifies what minimum set of actions an end user can perform on a supporting node when using the controlling node.
Each section describing a required functionality indicates the command(s) that MUST be transmitted on the Z-Wave radio.
Fields not present or described in the mandatory command(s) MAY be used freely by the controlling node either automatically or based on user input.

Fields indicated as "user defined" MUST be filled based on end user input. In this case, the end user MUST be able to select any value. (e.g. if the field is 2 bytes long, values from 0 to 65535 MUST be available)

Fields indicated as "User defined among supported" MUST be filled based on user input and the supported values by the supporting node. The controlling node MUST allow the end user to set values supported by a supporting node even if it does not know what a given value represents.
Fields indicated as "User defined among x..y and z" MUST be filled based on user input and MUST be able to select between the indicated values.
The product documentation MUST point out how to perform each action associated to the minimum end user functionalities required by a Command Class.

Like a supporting node implements a version of its supported Command Classes, a controlling node MUST also implement a given version of a Command Class it controls. A node controlling version 3 of a Command Class will be able to control the functionalities of version 1, 2 and 3 supporting nodes.

If a controlling node controls a node supporting a lower version, it MUST use the commands and format corresponding to the version it controls and MUST NOT use the fields described in the mandatory commands if they belong to a newer version.

A node controlling a Command Class is not mandated to interview, provide minimum end user functionality or show node properties belonging to a newer version of the actual Command Class."

When a version is indicated in the mandatory interview or mandatory commands for end user functionalities, it MUST represent the minimum common version number between the supporting and controlling node. For example, with a version 4 controlling node and version 2 supporting node, the interview, minimum end user functionalities and properties MUST follow version 1 and 2 indications.

formItem.itemHeader: Command Classes not present in the Command Class Control Specification
formItem.itemDescription: A node MAY advertise that it controls a Command Class not (yet) defined in the Command Class Control Specification (SDS14223) during certification.
The DUT controls Command Classes that are not defined in the Command Class Control Specification (SDS14223)
formItem.itemNote: Use the below text field to list all Command Classes that are controlled by the DUT but are NOT defined in SDS14223.

formItem.itemDescription:
In this case, the controlling node MUST comply with the following guidelines:
  • It MUST use all Get type commands to read the nodes capabilities during the node interview.
  • It SHOULD provide the end user actions using all Set type Commands available in the Command Class.
  • It SHOULD show or let the end user access all relevant state/property/configuration relating to the Command Class using the Report type Commands available in the Command Class.
A controller following this guideline is likely to be compliant when a new control specification is released for an actual Command Class.
The DUT only controls Command Classes that are defined in the Command Class Control Specification (SDS14223)

formItem.itemHeader: Filtering Security Class for controlling nodes
formItem.itemDescription: For Command Classes supported securely, a controlling node MUST discard the command from a supporting node if not received at the highest common security level between the controlling node and the sending S2 node.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Controlling nodes - Receiving commands at lower security level

formItem.itemDescription: A controlling node MUST NOT discard a command if the sending node does not support the S2 Command Class.
formItem.itemWikiLink: Controlling nodes - Receiving commands at lower security level

formItem.itemDescription: Any Z-Wave Plus v2 node controlling Command Classes (not using association groups) MUST discover the destination capabilities using every Security Class. If it intends to create associations between 2 other nodes, it MUST also discover which keys have been granted to both nodes.
formItem.itemNote:
Note: If the controlling node is the SIS, it SHOULD skip the discovery as it knows which keys have been granted. If the controlling node is not the SIS or does not know which security levels to use with a destination, it follows the discovery sequence recommended in section "Controlling nodes: Security Class learning" of the Z-Wave Plus v2 Device Type Specification (SDS14224).

DT:00.21.001D.2, DT:00.22.0005.1

formItem.itemTitle: The DUT controls one or more Command Classes via Association Groups
formItem.itemNote: Note: If this device controls Command Classes only via Association Groups this field must be selected. If the selection is not possible due to a disabled radio button please deselect the "Control" role for all Command Classes in the Command Class sections above.

formItem.itemDescription: Use the text field below to list the Command Classes (including the Command Class version) that are controlled via Association Groups.
Even if using a Command Class for controlling other nodes via association groups, the usage MUST comply with the Command Class description and the controlling node use properly formed commands.

If a controlling node controls a node supporting a lower version, it MUST use the commands and format corresponding to the version it controls and MUST NOT use the fields described in the mandatory commands if they belong to a newer version.
